title: US House in chaos as McCarthy withdraws
text:
US Congress in chaos after McCarthy quits Speaker race Demetri Sevastopulo and Gina Chon in Washington ©AP California Republican congressman Kevin McCarthy 
Kevin McCarthy, the California Republican congressman who was expected to replace John Boehner as Speaker of the House of Representatives, has withdrawn from the race, in a big victory for anti-establishment conservatives who have claimed two political scalps in as many weeks. 
The Republican party, which has a big majority in the House, planned to elect its candidate for Speaker at noon on Thursday. But in a dramatic development minutes before the vote, Mr McCarthy told colleagues that he was no longer the right person to hold what is the most powerful position in the House. More As it happened Republican debate IN US Politics & Policy US admits ‘mistake’ in Afghan air strike 
“If we are going to be united and be strong, we need to have a new face,” Mr McCarthy said flanked by his family following his withdrawal. 
He took the decision after it became clear that the Freedom Caucus, a small but vocal group affiliated with the Tea Party, had sufficient support to prevent him from getting the 218 votes needed to become Speaker from members of the Republican party. 
The development throws the succession plan into chaos. Mr Boehner pushed back the vote following a request from Mr McCarthy. 
“Everything is very fluid,” said Charlie Dent, a Pennsylvania congressman who opposes the Tea Party push against the Republican leadership. 
The outcome also has implications for the US fiscal situation. Congress must raise the debt ceiling by November 5 to enable the country to meet its interest obligations. But the Republican turmoil will complicate efforts to reach a deal given the acrimony inside the party and a widely held stance in the Tea Party that the ceiling should not be raised from its current level of $18tn. 
The chaotic situation on Capitol Hill mirrors a trend in US politics, and particularly within the Republicans, that is playing out across the nation and on the presidential campaign trail. 
Donald Trump and two other outsiders — Ben Carson and Carly Fiorina — have vaulted to the top of the Republican presidential contender field on anti-establishment sentiment directed at Washington. 
“Kudos to Kevin McCarthy for putting others before himself,” Mr Carson told CNN. 
In the Democratic party, Bernie Sanders has been propelled by a similar insurgent movement — albeit with different policy goals — that is frustrated with policies pushed by Hillary Clinton , the frontrunner for the Democratic nomination, and the attitudes of other mainstream politicians in the party. Everything is very fluid. It’s in flux 
- Charlie Dent, Pennsylvania Republican 
The decision by Mr McCarthy comes two weeks after Mr Boehner, a 13-term congressman from Ohio, announced his resignation in a move to prevent “prolonged leadership turmoil” in the party. 
Supporters of the Freedom Caucus argue that the Republican leadership has failed to block Mr Obama — on everything from the Iran nuclear deal to the Obamacare health insurance plan — despite having their largest majority since 1928. 
But Republican critics have hit back that the constitution makes it very difficult to overturn policies implemented by a president unless you have a two-thirds majority in both houses of Congress. The competing views have exposed a schism in the party that is no closer to being resolved. 
Mr McCarthy met the Freedom Caucus on Thursday after learning that its members planned to support Daniel Webster, a Florida politician who told the Republican conference that he was an “instrument of God” when explaining why he was running, according to people who were in the meeting. In depth
